entry.title: Public Policy Forum to Explore Current U.S. Drug Policy
entry.summary: Mexican narcotics-related violence has spilled over into the American Southwest, and California is debating legalizing marijuana in order to generate tax revenue. President Barack Obama's attorney general has indicated he will end raids on medial marijuana dispensaries that comply with state laws. These and other drug-related issues will be the focus of a RAND public policy forum: "Drug Policy in 2009: Are We Still a Nation at War?"

entry.title: Andrew Weiss Named to Lead RAND Business Leaders Forum, Center for Russia and Eurasia

link.title: RAND Center for Russia and Eurasia

entry.summary: Former government and business leader Andrew Weiss has been named executive director of the RAND Business Leaders Forum and the director of the RAND Center for Russia and Eurasia, RAND Corporation President and CEO James A. Thomson announced today.

entry.title: U.S.-Mexico Strategic Partnership Needed to Help Mexico Improve Its Security Institutions

link.title: MG-876 | Security in Mexico: Implications for U.S. Policy Options
RB-9444 | What Are U.S. Policy Options for Dealing with Security in Mexico?

entry.summary: The United States should forge a strategic partnership with Mexico that emphasizes reform and long-term institution building as a way to battle the ongoing drug war and other security challenges that face Mexico.

entry.title: Drug Education Also Helps Curb Risky Sexual Behavior
entry.summary: School-based drug education programs for adolescents can have a long-term positive impact on sexual behavior in addition to curbing substance abuse.

entry.title: Economic Costs of Major Oil Supply Disruption Pose Risk to U.S. National Security

link.title: MG-838 | Imported Oil and U.S. National Security
RB-9448 | Does Imported Oil Threaten U.S. National Security?

entry.summary: While on a net basis the United States imports nearly 60 percent of the oil it consumes, this reliance on imported oil is not by itself a major national security threat. The economic costs of a major disruption in global oil supplies&amp;amp;mdash;including higher prices for American consumers&amp;amp;mdash;pose the greatest risk to the United States.

entry.title: Records From Coalition Provisional Authority Shed Light on Occupation of Iraq

link.title: MG-847 | Occupying Iraq: A History of the Coalition Provisional Authority

entry.summary: The record of the U.S.-led Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA) in Iraq after the fall of Saddam Hussein compares favorably to that of many other U.S. efforts at post-conflict reconstruction, particularly in the areas of economic and public reforms. However, these achievements were undermined and overshadowed by the U.S. failure to protect the Iraqi population from the criminals and extremists among them who pulled Iraq into civil war.

entry.title: Ellen Nolte Joins RAND Europe as Director of Health and Healthcare Team
entry.summary: Ellen Nolte, formerly senior lecturer at the London School of Hygiene &amp;amp;amp; Tropical Medicine, has joined RAND Europe as the new director of the health and healthcare team. RAND Europe is a policy research organisation based in Cambridge UK whose research agenda includes the study of a broad range of health policy issues.

entry.title: U.S. Strategy Should Avoid Inflating Iran's Role in Middle East Instability, Exploit Constraints on Iranian Power and Seek Areas of Engagement

link.title: MG-781 | Dangerous But Not Omnipotent: Exploring the Reach and Limitations of Iranian Power in the Middle East
RB-9422 | A New U.S. Policy Paradigm Toward Iran

entry.summary: Iran's rise as a regional power presents a key foreign policy and security challenge to the United States, but its reach may be more limited than Western conventional wisdom suggests, according to a RAND Corporation study issued today. U.S. strategy must recognize Iran's role as an influential, but not omnipotent, player in the Middle East and work to exploit existing barriers to Iran's harmful activities, while simultaneously seeking areas of engagement.

entry.title: Paul G. Kaminski Elected To Lead RAND Corporation Board of Trustees
entry.summary:
Paul G. Kaminski, a technology company executive and former Pentagon official, has been elected chairman of the RAND Corporation Board of Trustees, RAND President and CEO James A. Thomson announced today. Kaminski previously was vice chairman of the RAND Board.
Karen Elliott House, former publisher of the Wall Street Journal, also has been elected vice chairman of the Board, Thomson said. RAND is a nonprofit research organization

entry.title: Limiting Work Hours For Medical Residents Could Cost $1.6 Billion Annually
entry.summary: New recommendations to limit the work hours of medical residents and improve their educational conditions could cost the nation's teaching hospitals about $1.6 billion annually to hire substitute workers, though society may benefit if such changes reduce medical errors as intended.

entry.title: RAND Europe's Senior Advisor Takes Up New Chair in Health Services Research at University of Cambridge
entry.summary: One of RAND Europe's senior advisors, Professor Martin Roland CBE, has accepted the position of professor of health services research within the University of Cambridge's School of Clinical Medicine with immediate effect. He will continue his role at RAND Europe, a policy research organisation based in Cambridge UK, as special avisor to the health and healthcare research team in addition to his new professorship.

entry.title: RAND Experts Available To Discuss North Korea Missile Launches, Nuclear Test
entry.summary: Over the past few days, North Korea has detonated a nuclear device and test-fired several short-range missiles, including two early Tuesday, despite strong condemnation from the international community, including China and Russia, its historic allies.

entry.title: RAND Experts Available To Discuss Lebanese Parliamentary Elections
entry.summary: On June 7, citizens of the Republic of Lebanon will cast their ballots to elect a new Parliament. Several RAND Corporation experts are available to discuss the implications of this important election and what the ramifications may be for U.S. interests and the Obama administration.

entry.title: California's Preschool System Can Be Improved Now, When Resources Are Scarce, and In the Future

link.title: MG-889 | Preschool Adequacy and Efficiency in California: Issues, Policy Options, and Recommendations
RB-9452 | Strategies for Advancing Preschool Adequacy and Efficiency in California
TR-537 | Who Is Ahead and Who Is Behind? Gaps in School Readiness and Student Achievement in the Early Grades for California's Children
TR-538 | Early Care and Education in the Golden State: Publicly Funded Programs Serving California's Preschool-Age Children
TR-539 | Prepared to Learn: The Nature and Quality of Early Care and Education for Preschool-Age Children in California

entry.summary: California can improve its early childhood education system in an era of fiscal crisis and lay the foundation for improving access and quality in the future when more resources are available.

entry.title: RAND Announces New Pricing Strategy and Partnerships for E-Books
entry.summary: The RAND Corporation announced today that it has revised the suggested retail pricing on all RAND e-books to $9.95 each. RAND e-books are available through a wide variety of wholesale and retail partners.

entry.title: Equity Concerns Raised by Transportation Congestion Pricing Can Be Addressed To Make Approach Viable

link.title: TR-680 | Equity and Congestion Pricing: A Review of the Evidence

entry.summary: Policymakers need to address equity concerns early when implementing congestion pricing to improve traffic flow, as each situation is unique and must be evaluated on a case-by-case basis.

entry.title: U.S. Freight System Modernization Necessary to Reduce Bottlenecks, Improve Security

link.title: MG-883 | Fast-Forward: Key Issues in Modernizing the U.S. Freight-Transportation System for Future Economic Growth
RB-9457 | Modernizing the U.S. Freight-Transportation System for Future Economic Growth

entry.summary: The long-term efficiency and effectiveness of the U.S. freight transportation system is threatened by bottlenecks, inefficient use of some parts of the infrastructure components, vulnerability to disruptions, and crucial environmental and energy concerns.

entry.title: California Parolees Have a High Need for Health Services, but Accessing Services Is a Challenge
entry.summary: Inmates released from California prisons have a high need for drug treatment, health care and mental health services, but they face barriers to accessing such aid because many return to communities where health care services are severely strained.

entry.title: RAND Experts Available to Discuss New U.N. Sanctions on North Korea, Upcoming U.S. Summit with South Korea
entry.summary: The RAND Corporation has several experts available to discuss the just-announced United Nations sanctions on North Korea, as well as next week's summit between President Barack Obama and South Korean President Lee Myung-bak. RAND experts are prepared to answer questions on the potential impacts of the sanctions, the likelihood of sanction enforcement, potential North Korean responses, the U.S./ROK alliance, and the principle of extended deterrence and how it applies to the alliance.

entry.title: Higher Co-Payments Discourage Patients With Newly Diagnosed Chronic Illnesses From Starting Drug Treatment
entry.summary: Patients newly diagnosed with hypertension, diabetes or high cholesterol are significantly more likely to delay initiating recommended drug treatment if they face higher co-payments for medications.
